physical_appearance:This painting is a montage of scenes of crowds paying tribute to the martyrs of the war. At the top right
 there is a tomb with a portrait
 and a signboard showing \u0027MacRitchie Reservoir\u0027. The top left of the painting shows troops marching while waving the Allied flags. At the bottom of the picture
 there is a group carrying black and white banners. There is a signature in the left of the painting.

sgcool_label_text:This painting belongs to a larger collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.\r\n\r\nThis painting is a tribute to the Force 136 members and other martyrs of the war.

metadata.physical_appearance: This painting is a montage of scenes of crowds paying tribute to the martyrs of the war. At the top right, there is a tomb with a portrait, and a signboard showing 'MacRitchie Reservoir'. The top left of the painting shows troops marching while waving the Allied flags. At the bottom of the picture, there is a group carrying black and white banners. There is a signature in the left of the painting.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This painting belongs to a larger collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This painting is a tribute to the Force 136 members and other martyrs of the war.
